overview_of_class:
GEN_MUS 175-0 Selected Topics in Music Literature: Music and Film
This course surveys the history of music in the cinema, exploring questions such as: Where does the music come from? Why is it there at all? Are we meant to pay attention to it? Why this music and not some other? What does the music mean? How do we know? Are political or ethical implications attached to certain ways of using music? Does music construct our interpretation of images, or vice versa? What is its relationship to other elements of film sound? What range of functions can it serve? How and why has film-music practice changed, and what continuities have persisted? Our primary texts will consist of a wide variety of films, centered on the classical Hollywood cinema (of the 1930s-50s) but extending back to silent film (and its live musical accompaniment) and forward to today's audio technologies and globalized entertainment industries. Orchestral scores and soundtracks based on popular music will both be considered; American movies will be juxtaposed to international cinema; and the conventions of Hollywood will be contrasted with critiques and challenges to its norms. No musical background is required as prerequisite.

GEN_MUS 175-0 Selected Topics in Music Literature: The Beatles and the Rolling Stones
The Beatles versus the Stones: this course will examine what these great rock and roll bands have in common and how they differ with respect to melodies, chord progressions, lyrics, styles of singing and playing their instruments, live performances, production, and cultural context. We'll also discuss A Hard Day's Night and Gimme Shelter, the high points of these bands' legacies on film. The course will focus on the bands in the years 1962-1972, but will also touch on influences like Chuck Berry and the best of the post-Exile Stones. Assignments will include short papers and an in-class presentation. No prior musical knowledge or training is required for this class.

overview_of_class:
"Holding the Press Accountable: Laws, Norms, Markets & Architecture"

This course has a practical goal and an intellectual one. The practical one is directed at your inner publisher (we all have one): to make you your own best risk counselor and to prepare you to talk knowledgeably with legal counsel about your work or the work of others. The latter is to situate those liability risks in the normative, economic and architectural features of the U.S. and international media systems. The course is rooted in the constitutional, common law, statutory and regulatory systems of media accountability used in the United States as they have developed in the 20th century, and especially since 1964. Wherever possible or useful we consult comparative law examples, mostly from the European Union. We begin the course normatively, by putting all this in the context of First Amendment theory and doctrine. After that it's communications law and policy, and each week we'll consider problems practical and principled.

overview_of_class:
This course provides rigorous grounding in the foundations of reporting and writing news stories. Medill students learn to report in the world's best news lab - the streets of Chicago. Starting the first week, students will cover breaking news, enterprise and a range of other stories that ground them in reporting fundamentals. Working closely with the school's acclaimed editors/instructors, students master basics that prepare them for success in print, broadcast or online media.

The fundamental lessons include understanding what news is; finding news stories and sources; interviewing effectively and efficiently; researching stories; verifying facts; writing clean, crisp news stories with impact; presenting information in alternative forms; and conducting oneself ethically professionally and ethically.

For the final four weeks, the classroom becomes a simulated newsroom, where students cover a "beat" - that's a content specialty within a designated geographic area in Chicago or its suburbs - and file stories with a daily deadline. It's fast-paced, intense and fun. Students leave News Reporting with skills and confidence they can tackle fast-breaking and complex stories

overview_of_class: The course will use a case-method approach to explore and dissect the decisions editors make in pursuit of fundamental goals - e.g. truth/accuracy, fairness, timeliness, reflection of community, audience focus. overview_of_class: In this class, small teams of students develop prototypes of media businesses or publications, either as new product concepts for existing publishers or as entrepreneurial ventures. After researching the needs of audiences/users, examining the competitive landscape and identifying business and revenue possibilities, students build prototypes along with marketing strategies and business plans. We offer two different versions of the course: a two-quarter version (winter and spring quarters) in which Medill MSJ's are on teams that include students from other Northwestern schools, and a one-quarter version (summer quarter) for Medill MSJ's only. The course gives students real-world experience in what it takes to develop a successful media product and provides them with skills and techniques they can use to lead media innovation inside a company or in a startup environment.

overview_of_class: This is a survey course dedicated to the pretty simple proposition that sports are more than entertainment, more than popular culture. Sports are a social institution no less than education, religion, or the military, and no less important. Sports are also oldest form of 'reality television' and the most expensive, highest-earning media product. This course is intended to help students interested in sports and sports journalism to improve their craft by identifying and explaining social meanings in the world of sports. In short, it's a sports class that looks at society through the lens of sports. Many are quick to see sports as a metaphorical training ground for 'life'. Life is this case includes commerce and industry, domestic and international politics (including war), gender identity and sexuality, race and ethnic relations, religion and spirituality, and popular culture from fashion to video games. This course considers sports in some of these various contexts. We do it through weekly monitoring of sports media, documentary films, and research and writing assignments.

overview_of_class:
AFST 276-0-20 "African Literature in Translation " , Summer 2016, Richard Lepine

The course is primarily a survey of African oral verbal arts traditions, with an additional focus on the links between these traditions and African films. The original works of art, the objects of study in the course, are not literature in the strict sense of the term-written verbal art-but rather take form in oral performance or electronic media like film, TV, radio, recorded disks, and web-based digital media. However, in print and in English translation, the course examples from various genres of African oral verbal arts performances (riddles, poetry, proverbs, panegyric, folktales, trickster tales, hero tales, epics) are all experienced as literature for purposes of analysis and interpretation. Four African films will also serve as primary course "texts": Wend Kuuni (1982; Gaston Kaboré, dir.; Burkina Faso), Keita: Heritage of the Griot (1995; Dani Kouyaté, dir.; Burkina Faso); La vie est belle/Life Is Rosy (1987; Ngangura Mweze and Bernard Lamy, dirs.; Zaïre [Democratic Republic of Congo]), and Yeelen (Souleymane Cissé, Mali, 1987, 105 min.). A major goal of the course is to explore the analytic approaches employed by scholars Harold Scheub and Robert Cancel, specialists in African oral traditions and their relationships with other arts media.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Students attend two 150-minute group lecture sessions each week in a University "smart classroom." All coursework is web-based via a dedicated Canvas LMS site; the required Cancel course text has integrated digitized audio and video. The teaching method consists of the presentation of the artistic and scholarly texts; guidance through the multimedia learning resources connected to the material; classroom question and discussion; ongoing assessment and feedback on individual contributions to collaborative LMS-based projects; and a revisable draft process for the midterm and final compositions. Since a major goal of the course is the development of practical analytic strategies, part of that process involves composing a number of brief writing assignments: graded and ungraded short essays, some done in class, some submitted as homework. Three longer (roughly 5 to 10 page) interpretive studies are required: a wiki contribution posted to to the course's Canvas site as a collaborative project, and two traditional-style research and presentation compositions, one due at midterm and the other in the last week of classes. There is no final examination.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Wiki Project: In examining the oral performance genre of "lyric" (for course purposes, a generic term for all types of spoken and sung poetry) each participant will choose one of the 210 verses which make up the Yoruba divination system known as Sixteen Cowries. The verse the student chooses will then become the subject of a personal interpretation to be presented on a wiki accessed through the course's Canvas site.
Assessment is primarily based on the writing assignments. The three major writing projects (contribution to the collaboratively-built wiki, midterm revisable draft composition, final revisable draft composition) are each worth 30% of the final course grade; the smaller in-class or take-home writings assignments will be averaged for the remaining 10% of the grade.

overview_of_class:
AFST 390-0 Special Topics: Anthropology of African Civil Wars (Combined with ANTHRO 390-0-20)

Understanding civil war is a central intellectual (and political) challenge of the contemporary global world, involving insistent questions about terrorism, genocide, child soldiers, sexual violence, etc. This course examines a variety of cases of contemporary African civil wars but is framed by general questions about the logic of violence in any social context. The course focuses on: (a) the micro-practices of violence in the daily organization of civil war, especially the language and ideology of violence invoked in those social practices, and (b) the relationship between everyday social practices of violence and macro-level structural forces of politics and economics. Readings are mainly from anthropology but other social sciences that use ethnographic methods to study civil war will be discussed.

descriptions.value: Classes will be organized as a combination of lecture and seminar discussion, with an emphasis on a case study approach that focuses on applying key concepts and analytical principles to particular ethnographic cases. Segments of ethnographic films will also be used as case material for discussion in class.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Four short papers - "problem sets" - of 2- 2 ½ double-spaced papers are required as targeted analytical and ethnographic exercises for students to clarify the conceptual framework being built up in the course as applied to the case material. Students will present and discuss their problem sets in class. The final is a take-home term paper of 8 - 10 double-spaced pages. The final paper will allow students to relate key analytical themes of the course to the documentation of civil war and child soldiers in the novel and film called "Beasts on No Nation." The four short papers are each worth 10 points of the grade, and the final paper is worth 50 points. Ten points of the grade is based on seminar participation.

descriptions.value: This course is part of the four-course introductory biology sequence. The cell biology course covers mechanisms the cell uses to compartmentalize and transport proteins, to move, to regulate growth and death, and to communicate with their environments.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the class, a student is expected to be able to:
1. Explain the importance of membrane function as well as the role of membrane lipids, protein components and membrane organization in eukaryotic cells.
2. Explain how cellular components are targeted and distributed to different regions and compartments of a cell.
3. Explain how cellular components of the cytoskeleton support a variety of cell functions, such as cell shape, division, movement, sensing the environment, and cell-cell communication.
4. Explain how cell send, receive, and respond to signals from their environment, including other cells.
5. Explain how cells coordinate and regulate cell division.
6. Explain how an imbalance or mutation in normal cell processes can lead to cancer and other disease states.

overview_of_class: Shakespeare's Social Networks Like much of what Shakespeare wrote four centuries ago, Hamlet's famous "To be or not to be" speech?a contemplation of suicide, the afterlife, injustice, and the inability to turn thought into action?has gone viral. While Hamlet intends the speech to be private, Shakespeare stages it for a public audience composed of people from all walks of English society. What appears to be an expression of individuality, then, is also shaped by and for the social networks in which the character and playwright lived. Would Hamlet have spoken differently had he known his words would go viral? Twenty-first century social networks such as Facebook have changed the way we present ourselves to the world, how we interpret and judge the experiences of others, how we define friendship, and how we receive and share information. In this course we will employ perspectives and tools from the digital age as we read a selection of Shakespeare's plays, including Hamlet, The Winter's Tale, Merchant of Venice, Macbeth, Othello, and Henry V. We'll experiment with different kinds of literary analysis, combining old-fashioned "close reading" of language at the sentence-level with newer kinds of "distant reading" that track thematic and rhetorical patterns across multiple plays. We will pay particular attention to similarities and differences between our own social networks and those in Shakespeare's plays and the culture in which they were originally performed.

overview_of_class:
Urbanologist Yi Fu Tuan writes, "What begins as undifferentiated space becomes place when we get to know it better and endow it with values." In The Untouchables, Sean Connery tells Kevin Costner, "You want to get Capone? Here's how you get Capone. He pulls a knife, you pull a gun. He puts one of yours in the hospital, you put one of his in the morgue. That's the Chicago way." In this class, we will examine "the Chicago way" from many different angles in order to interrogate the values with which various artists have endowed Chicago. We will read in a broad range of media: journalism, poetry, song, fiction, film, and sequential art to see how a sense of Chicago as a place works over time. We will pay close attention to depictions of the construction of American identity, and to the role of the artist and intellectual in the city.

Texts Include: Nelson Algren's Chicago: City on the Make and The Neon Wilderness; Richard Wright's Native Son; Stuart Dybek's The Coast of Chicago; journalism by Ben Hecht, Mike Royko and others; short fiction by Sandra Cisneros, James T. Farrell and others; poetry by Carl Sandburg, Gwendolyn Brooks, Tony Fitzpatrick and others; the films The Untouchables, The Blues Brothers, Call Northside 777, and Barbershop; the graphic novel 100 Bullets: First Shot, Last Call.

This course fulfills the requirements for distribution area VI: Literature and Fine Arts.

overview_of_class: What is the appeal of horrifying literature? From today's horror fiction exploring the limits of insanity and the paranormal back to its origins in Gothic tales featuring Indian captivity, frontier violence, and the terrors of slavery in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, American literature encodes a long history of fascination with the macabre. We will consider the aesthetic experience of terror along with the social and political function of works of dark fiction such as Charles Brockden Brown's Edgar Huntly, Edgar Allan Poe's "The Murders of the Rue Morgue," Charles Chesnutt's The Conjure Woman, Henry James' The Turn of the Screw, and Tony Morrison's Beloved. We will examine the rise of the Gothic and the related genre of horror in relation to Enlightenment philosophical, scientific, and political thought along with the history of racialization and nationalism in the United States. Our readings will be supplemented by contemporary horror movies such as Alfred Hithcock's Psycho, Roman Polanski's Rosemary's Baby, and Stanley Kubrick's The Shining.

overview_of_class: This course will introduce students to queer performance in the United States from the 1970s onward. We will examine a broad range of queer performance productions and practices situated in various settings, from activist street protest to theater plays, from mainstream media performance to performances in LGBTQ nightlife scenes. Some of the performers and troupes we will examine are Tango Lesbiango, ActUP, Ron Athey, RuPaul, Micha Cárdenas, Mangos with Chili, The Cockettes, Sister Spit, Margaret Cho, and Sins Invalid. Through seminar discussions, lectures, student presentations, and writings assignments (short essays/performance reviews/blogs), students will become familiar with methods and theories from queer studies and performance studies and will learn to apply them to the critical analysis and historicization of queer performances circulating on both local and national scales. Together we will unpack how "queer" is deployed within the performances we examine. How is "queer," as a term that can either describe an identity or ways of being/doing, troubled and revised by the performers to account for the intersections of gender, sexuality, race, disability, and/or ethnicity? Integrated into the course curriculum will be a group trip to a local festival or theater, wherein students will have an opportunity to apply the methods and theories learned in the course to observing, documenting, and analyzing live, queer performance.

This course is a survey of the major events and developments in pre-industrial European history. It takes students from the age of the Crusades to the eve of the French Revolution, a period of tremendous transformation which set the stage for modernity. We will look at the major themes of European history during the period?high medieval culture, the Renaissance, the Reformation, the emergence of modern science, colonies and commerce, changes in political and military structures, and the Enlightenment. There will be a heavy emphasis on primary sources and the how historical narratives are constructed to help us understand the evolution of ideas and institutions in European history. overview_of_class: This course introduces students to the outlines of modern European history, from the French Revolution through the European Union Maastricht Treaty. Focusing on the multiple political organizations and reorganizations of Europe, this course traces the concept of the modern nation state, the widespread acceptance of this particular form of political organization, and the emergence of the European Union as a possible challenge to the nation state model. Students will also explore major social, cultural, economic, and technological changes of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, using both primary and secondary source material. This course will argue that the nation state is not an obvious or natural form of political organization, but was constructed during the 19th century and then challenged from opposing perspectives by fascism and communism in the 20th century, resulting in the emergence of the European Union as an attempt to ensure security through national integration.

overview_of_class: "Years of hope, days of rage." The Sixties remain one of the most studied and controversial time periods in United States history. Characterized by many as a time of Civil Rights, Free Speech, and the Sexual Revolution, this period also brought us the Vietnam War, the New Right, and the waning power of industrial unions. Moreover, historians continue to debate when the period known as "the Sixties" actually began and ended. Born out of a postwar period of expanding national expectation, the Sixties gave birth to our modern "culture wars" and continue to mean different things to all those who experienced or examine them. Through political, social, and cultural history, this course will explore the causes, content, and consequences of the period's many paradoxes. It will demonstrate how unresolved tensions in what scholars have called the "liberal consensus" in turn set the stage for the "rise of the Right" and "Age of Reagan." Finally, we will evaluate why the history of this period remains so influential.

overview_of_class: In 1972, there were 300,000 Americans in prison. Today there are 2.3 million. Through literature, African writers of fiction critique their societies and imagine their pasts. How can their works help us understand the African past? This course will explore how the most iconic works of modern African literature are informed by history. The novels we will read are all written by African authors, and in many cases are about a historical experience to which they were or are connected. These novels are a form of historical imagination about ?how it was' living in particular cities and regions of Africa and experiencing particular events in African history (such as the Rwandan genocide, apartheid in South Africa, or European colonial conquest). Although literature shares with history an attention to narrative and imagination, it departs from history in not being bound by evidence or fidelity to sources. We will explore how this is both the strengths and weakness of using literature to understand the past. How do fictional treatments of historical events differ as well as overlap with how historians understand the past?

No background in African history is required for the course.

overview_of_class: Globalization is arguably the most powerful force shaping international and domestic politics today. When observers discuss the effects of globalization, they may refer to any of a number of its different facets: economic, political, social, and environmental. In this course we will focus primarily on economic globalization - the increase in the cross-border flows of goods and services, workers, firms, and money. This course is intended to take stock of globalization in light of the global economic meltdown. What is globalization? Are its effects on the economic fortunes of individuals in wealthy democracies different than in developing countries? Does the reduction of barriers to economic exchange harm national cultures? Is terrorism linked to globalization? Does globalization erode or enhance American military power? Has globalization gone too far - or has it not gone far enough? These are the kinds of questions that will be discussed in the course. The course is organized around six major topics: (1) conceptualizing globalization; (2) assessing the constituent parts of economic globalization (trade, finance, multinational production, and immigration); (3) how different national styles of capitalism in the advanced industrial countries have adjusted to pressure from rising economic globalism; (4) how developing countries joined the globalization bandwagon and whether global economic inequality has increased or decreased as a result; (5) the consequences of increasing economic integration for distinct national cultures; (6) the challenges to globalization posed by transnational terrorism, geopolitical rivalries, and the series of economic crises after 2008.

From civil war to nuclear weapons, mafia thugs to oligarchs, and natural resource battles to modern-day dictators, Russia has experienced a remarkable range of political phenomena over the past two decades. This course analyzes the political, economic, and foreign policy revolutions that shook Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Through the lens of the Russian experience, we will examine key concepts in comparative politics, such as revolution, regime change, market formation, nationalism, and state building.

Whether you plan to professionally engage in politics, conduct international business, or simply be a well-educated global citizen, you need to know about Russia. It is the world's largest country by geographic size and the ninth largest country by population. It remains one of the world's only two nuclear superpowers. It is the world's largest oil producer and exporter. And it widely is considered - along with China, India, and Brazil - to be one of the world's most important emerging economies.

overview_of_class:
Prof. Jeffrey Rice "Spectacular Protest" Summer 2016
Anti-establishment protest comes in many forms: at one end we might have candle light vigils, at the other end violent revolution. Somewhere in between is where most political protest occurs with demonstrations, grass root organizations, lobbying etc. But somewhere in this spectrum resides what I call "Spectacular Protest" by which I mean activities that use theatricality to ?capture' a moment leaving people to identify with the gesture of anti-establishment behavior. Examples may come from music (The Sex Pistols or Bob Dylan or Chance the Rapper), from art (Marcel Duchamp), from theater (Bertolt Brecht) or from new variations on political protest (the Yippies' nomination of a pig,?Pigasus' for President in 1968.)
This class will be a discussion of these rather public and theatrical moments of protest and how they galvanize public space, even if for a brief moment of time. The more ambitious aspect of this class is to determine whether these moments of protest can rise above juvenilia or immature spectacle and result in social change. In other words, should we even call them "political"?
The examples we will cover in the brief time we have are (briefly) the Dada movement after World War One, the Situationist Movement in the 1960s (with their reinvention of Marx to explain the commodity in advanced capitalism), 1968 both in Paris ("Be Realistic, Demand the Impossible") and Chicago ("Stop the War in Vietnam) and lastly, "The Sex Pistols" and Punk.

overview_of_class: Africa remains the world's poorest continent. Despite renewed optimism in the recent years, the continent's overall economic performance is less than impressive and a source of animated debate both in academia and policy circles. After remarkable performance in the 1960s and the first half of 1970s, the continent suffered negative growth throughout the 1980s and the first half of the 1990s. Only a few countries managed to recover and return to the level of 1970 GDP per capita at the turn of the century. The first part of the course will analyze classical and alternative explanations to Africa's economic stagnation and underdevelopment. The second part will cover a range of responses and prescriptions, both orthodox and heterodox, to tackling growth stagnation and accelerating economic transformation.

overview_of_class: What is a psychological disorder, and can we really define what it means to be abnormal? Despite a long history of studying psychological disorders, there is no clear consensus when it comes to answering these questions: Our understandings of what constitute psychological disorders and how to best treat them vary considerably across different time periods and cultures. It is fascinating to learn about the complexity in even defining psychological disorders. At the same time, it is also frustrating, especially in the face of real psychological distress that many experience: If we cannot agree on what psychological disorders are, then how are we to study them and treat them? In this course, we will begin exploring these questions through an introduction to the major categories of psychological disorders as we currently (and historically) understand them and through the integration of related research findings. In addition to focusing on the symptoms and causes of these disorders, we will learn about some major approaches to diagnosis, assessment, and treatment. Finally, special attention will be paid to current and/or controversial issues in abnormal psychology.

overview_of_class: Lots of people have beliefs that other people think are just plain weird. Why do people have these beliefs? We'll examine some "weird" beliefs and try to understand what leads people to develop and maintain these beliefs. A complication arises since one person's "weird" belief may be another person's firmly held conviction. From this perspective, we'll also try to understand which beliefs are rational. overview_of_class: Psychology has traditionally focused on understanding mental illness, rather than factor that lead to optimal mental well-being. This seminar will instead focus upon the questions asked within the growing science of positive psychology. What is happiness?
